You raise a good point that even fact-checking websites, like all other media outlets, can have their own biases. However, there are some steps you can take to ensure you're using trustworthy fact-checking websites.

1. Check the fact-checker's reputation: Like news sources, fact-checking websites have reputations. You can look up their history and find out what people are saying about them. You can also check the methodology they use to verify facts and ensure it's transparent and unbiased.

2. Use a variety of fact-checking websites: Using multiple fact-checking websites can help reduce any potential bias. You may find that different fact-checkers verify or disprove claims in different ways, so using a selection of websites can give you a more complete picture.

3. Avoid fact-checking websites that align with your own beliefs: It's easy to fall into the trap of only using fact-checking websites that align with your personal beliefs or political views. Try to use a variety of sources, even those that challenge your own beliefs. This can help ensure you're getting a well-rounded perspective on issues.

4. Fact-check for yourself: You can also take a more active role in fact-checking by verifying information yourself. Check official sources, consult experts, and use common sense to evaluate claims. If you find conflicting information, take the time to investigate further and identify which sources are trustworthy.

Ultimately, it's important to approach all media with a critical eye and use multiple sources to verify information. While it's impossible to completely escape the influence of personal beliefs and opinions, by being informed and evaluating sources critically, you can separate fact from fiction and make informed decisions.
